title: Biden Defends Vaccine Stance  As Businesses Digest Mandate  ----  By Catherine Lucey and Sabrina Siddiqui
text:
WASHINGTON -- President Biden defended his sweeping new vaccination mandates to deal with the Covid-19 pandemic, as businesses worked to understand the rules and Republicans attacked them as overreach.

Mr. Biden and first lady Jill Biden traveled Friday morning to Brookland Middle School, 4 miles northeast of the White House. Responding to GOP criticism, he said scientists supported his plans and that Republicans who have fought against mask rules and other pandemic restrictions were being "cavalier" with the health of children and their communities. "We're playing for real here. This isn't a game," Mr. Biden said.

On Thursday, Mr. Biden unveiled his new approach to Covid-19, requiring vaccinations for employees of many private-sector businesses, healthcare personnel and federal contractors. The rules would apply to roughly 100 million workers, or two-thirds of all workers in the U.S. As of Friday, nearly 65% of the U.S. adult population was fully vaccinated.

Mr. Biden's six-part plan, which also includes efforts to improve access to testing and make Covid-19 treatments more widely available, comes amid a surge in infections and an increase in hospitalizations and deaths, the vast majority of them among the unvaccinated.

The coronavirus has killed more than 655,000 Americans, according to data from Johns Hopkins University, with the recent seven-day average of reported deaths about 1,500 a day, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of Johns Hopkins data.

The White House had previously shied away from vaccine mandates, but it is now framing the push as necessary to boost vaccinations, given the continuing resistance from some of the population.

Jeff Zients, Mr. Biden's Covid-19 coordinator, said that the highly transmissible Delta variant had changed the landscape, and that the administration believed the new requirements would offer a pathway out of the pandemic while also helping schools and the U.S. economy stay open.

"We know that vaccination requirements work," Mr. Zients told reporters Friday. "Vaccination requirements are the current standard employed by so many corporations. The president's actions will accelerate that number."

The effort drew swift condemnation from Republicans, with GOP governors in a number of states vowing to take legal action. Several Republican-led states have sought to ban or restrict vaccine mandates by employers.

South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster tweeted Thursday: "Rest assured, we will fight them to the gates of hell to protect the liberty and livelihood of every South Carolinian." Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp tweeted: "I will pursue every legal option available to the state of Georgia to stop this blatantly unlawful overreach by the Biden administration." The Republican National Committee also said it would sue to stop the vaccine mandate on employers.

On court challenges, Mr. Biden said Friday: "Have at it."

White House press secretary Jen Psaki said the administration didn't anticipate such "vehement opposition" from so many Republicans, given that the vaccine was developed under Republican former President Donald Trump. She also noted the Food and Drug Administration had given full authorization to the vaccine and warned of the extra risk to children posed by the Delta variant.

The administration's decision to institute more stringent vaccination requirements evolved over weeks and was born in part from growing frustration with Republican state leaders, according to people familiar with the planning.

Mandating vaccinations has been a common trajectory for other vaccines that were first introduced as voluntary with educational campaigns, and then later required for children entering schools. The Biden administration felt it had devoted enough time to education and had made the Covid-19 vaccines free and widely accessible, the people said.

Under Mr. Biden's plan, all employers with 100 or more employees would have to require that their workers be vaccinated or undergo at least weekly Covid-19 testing. The administration also plans to require vaccinations for workers in most healthcare settings that receive Medicare or Medicaid reimbursement, as well as federal employees in the executive branch and government contractors.

Some business groups have expressed support for the plan. In a statement, Business Roundtable President Joshua Bolten said the group "welcomes the Biden administration's continued vigilance in the fight against COVID."

Other business organizations said they were looking to understand the new requirements. A spokeswoman for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce said in a statement: "The Chamber will carefully review the details of the executive orders and associated regulations and will work to ensure that employers have the resources, guidance, and flexibility necessary to ensure the safety of their employees and customers and comply with public health requirements."

Companies including United Airlines Holdings Inc. and Tyson Foods Inc. are requiring all employees to be vaccinated. Others, such as Walmart Inc., McDonald's Corp. and Walt Disney Co., have said certain groups, such as managers or white-collar workers, need to take the shot.

The AFL-CIO, the nation's largest labor organization, said it supported the president's plan. Other unions faulted the initiative. American Federation of Government Employees National President Everett Kelley said in a statement: "We have said that changes like this should be negotiated with our bargaining units where appropriate."

---

Stephanie Armour contributed to this article.
